Most Nepenthes species require bright, indirect sunlight to grow well, but there are some species that can tolerate lower light conditions. Nepenthes species that naturally grow in the forest understory or in areas with limited sunlight are more adaptable to lower light conditions.

In general, Nepenthes can survive in lower light conditions, but their growth may be slower, and their pitchers may be smaller and less colorful. In low light conditions, Nepenthes may produce longer, narrower leaves that stretch towards the light. This is known as etiolation and can lead to a weakened plant.

If you need to grow Nepenthes in low light conditions, it is important to choose shade-tolerant Nepenthes species and provide them with appropriate care. You can also supplement natural light with artificial light, as mentioned earlier, to provide enough light for their growth.

It is important to note that Nepenthes may not thrive in extremely low light conditions, such as in a dark room or basement. In such cases, Nepenthes may struggle to survive and eventually die. Therefore, it is essential to provide Nepenthes with an adequate amount of light or choose a different plant species that is more suitable for your growing conditions.
